head.title: GStreamer Google Summer of Code: Static ORC

body.h1: GStreamer Google Summer of Code: Static Compilation for ORC

p.quot: Compile assembly code generated by Orc at build time.

ul.li: Sebastian Dr√∂ge, Wim Taymans, Luis de Bethencourt

body.p:
Orc is basically a simplified assembly language for data processing (no loops/jumps etc.), it's supposed to map to SIMD instructions on various architectures curently there are two things:
liborc, which is a JIT compiler that will at run-time take orc code (in some byte format) and generate machine code for the architecture in question on the fly and then execute that whenever there's a function call
we have C backup functions as .c files in the gstreamer source code, which are also compiled in when orc can't compile some code (for various reasons), or liborc is not available, then the C backup function will be used that's the current state of things.

Now, what one could also do is: use orcc at gstreamer build-time to compile assembly source code, and then have the compiler/assembler use that instead of the C backup function that's useful on e.g. iOS (where liborc can't generate code at runtime for security reasons, memory must be executable) but could also be useful when you know your target architecture, on embedded systems (then you don't need to link to liborc and generate stuff at runtime, you just pre-generate the assembly for your target arch and use that) so it involves some build system fiddling and making sure the assembly output orc generates is good
